thread.title: Williams, Pirates profit from sloppy Rays
thread.title_full: Williams, Pirates profit from sloppy Rays

title: Williams, Pirates profit from sloppy Rays
text:
Williams, Pirates profit from sloppy Rays Jaso's run in 1st 0:23 John Jaso scored the game's first run after Alec Sole commits an error at third base to open the scoring By Adam Berry and Bill Chastain / MLB.com | + 0 COMMENTS 
BRADENTON, Fla. -- Infielder Phil Gosselin had two hits, catcher Chris Stewart drove in a run and the Pirates capitalized on a handful of the Rays' mistakes in a 4-0 win at LECOM Park on Friday afternoon. 
Tampa Bay committed three errors, two of which led directly to Pittsburgh runs. John Jaso doubled and scored on Alec Sole's misplay at third base in the first inning. With two on and two outs in the fourth, Stewart hit a clean single to center field. Rays outfielder Mallex Smith 's throw sailed wide of the plate, two runs scored and Stewart wheeled around to third base after giving the Bucs a 3-0 lead. Stewart's RBI single, two score TB@PIT: Two runs score on Stewart's single and error Chris Stewart lines an RBI single to center field, scoring David Freese and Phil Gosselin scores on a throwing error Full Game Coverage 
Right-hander Trevor Williams , competing for the final spot in the Pirates' rotation, put together a dominant performance. Williams held the Rays scoreless for five innings, allowing three hits while striking out four and inducing six ground-ball outs. He was followed by most of the Pirates' "A" bullpen -- closer Tony Watson and setup men Daniel Hudson , Felipe Rivero and Juan Nicasio -- in the combined four-hit, one-walk shutout. 
Erasmo Ramirez started for the Rays and allowed one earned run on four hits and a walk while striking out four. Six of his other outs were groundouts, which bodes well for the right-hander, who looks to again be part of the Rays' bullpen in 2017. Ramirez's 1st-inning strikeout TB@PIT: Ramirez gets Bell swinging Erasmo Ramirez retires Josh Bell on a swinging strikeout in the 1st inning 
"[Getting ground balls] means I was working down in the strike zone," Ramirez said. "Making the hitters hit ground balls, that means a lot to a pitcher. That's way better because, you know, the Trop is a fly ball park. Can mean a lot of home runs. The more you get the ball on the ground, the more chances you'll have to succeed at Tropicana Field." 
Rays Up Next: The Rays will host the Red Sox on Saturday afternoon in a 1:05 p.m. ET contest at Charlotte Sports Park. Blake Snell will start and he'll be followed by Tommy Hunter and Justin Marks . Snell, who is penciled in to be the Rays' No. 4 starter, has had a tough spring, going 2-1 with a 5.65 ERA, including eight walks in 14 1/3 innings. Rays manager Kevin Cash noted that the left-hander needed to "flip a switch a little bit" to be ready for the season. Shawn Haviland will start for the Red Sox. Watch the game live on MLB.TV . 
Pirates Up Next: Top prospect Tyler Glasnow , making one of his final bids for the last spot in Pittsburgh's rotation, will start for the Pirates as they host the Tigers at LECOM Park at 1:05 p.m. on Saturday. Left-hander Steven Brault , competing for the same job, is slated to pitch after Glasnow. Reliever Jared Hughes is also scheduled to take the mound for the Bucs. Watch the game live on MLB.TV . 
Watch every out-of-market regular-season game live on MLB.TV . has covered the Pirates for MLB.com since 2015. Follow him on Twitter and Facebook , read his blog and listen to his podcast . Bill Chastain has covered the Rays for MLB.com since 2005. This story was not subject to the approval of Major League Baseball or its clubs. Share This
